questions.text: In the diagram provided, which enzymes are identified as E1 and E2, responsible for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pyruvate dehydrogenase and dihydrolipoyl transacetylase

Explanation:

  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is responsible for the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, a crucial step in aerobic glucose metabolism.
  • A deficiency in this complex leads to the accumulation of pyruvate, which is then shunted towards lactate production, resulting in lactic acidosis.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex:

dehydrogenase complex" data-author="" data-hash="11796" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="427" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/6yMTUtSDYeKjLVYStmOY1746433022.png" width="300" />

 

dehydrogenase complex" data-author="" data-hash="11798" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="400" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rx9qzB63H4OSsflR9P0n1746433050.png" width="400" />

 

  • Catalyzes the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in mitochondria.
  • A critical step in aerobic glucose metabolism, as it links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • Structure:
    • 5 Coenzymes - thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), lipoic acid, CoA, FAD, and NAD+.
    • 3 products: NADH, CO2, Acetyl-CoA.
    • 3 substrates: Pyruvate, NAD, CoA.
    • 3 subunits: E1 (PDH / PDC), E2 (dihydrolipoyl transacetylase), and E3 (dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase).
  • Irreversible reaction:
    • Pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is highly exergonic and irreversible, preventing direct synthesis of glucose from acetyl-CoA.
  • Regulation:
    • Inhibition: Acetyl-CoA, NADH, and ATP inhibit PDH to conserve glucose.
    • Phosphorylation: Kinase inactivates, and phosphatase activates PDH based on energy status.
    • Hormonal Control: Insulin activates PDH for fat synthesis
    • Calcium: Activates PDH during muscle contraction.
  • Clinical significance:
    • PDH complex deficiencies are rare but serious genetic disorders causing lactic acidosis, neurological issues, and developmental delays.
    • Thiamine deficiency, common in alcoholics, impairs PDH complex activity, leading to pyruvate accumulation and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Calcium

 

Explanation:

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by calcium in tissues, particularly in muscle cells.

 

Calcium and Muscle Contraction:

  • During muscle contraction, calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in response to a neural signal.
  • Calcium then binds to calmodulin, a calcium-binding protein, forming the calcium-calmodulin complex.
  • Activation of Phosphorylase Kinase: The calcium-calmodulin complex activates phosphorylase kinase, an enzyme that plays a key role in glycogen breakdown.
  • Activation of Glycogen Phosphorylase: The phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase activates it, which in turn stimulates the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, providing energy for muscle contraction.
  • Cofactor of glycogen phosphorylase is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)

questions.text: Which one of the following choices does not represent a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glycolysis

Explanation:

Glucagon is a hormone produced by the alpha cells of the pancreas that primarily increases blood glucose levels, especially during fasting or low glucose states.

  • It achieves this by stimulating processes that increase glucose availability and energy production.
  • Glycolysis is the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy (ATP).
  • Glucagon inhibits glycolysis in the liver to conserve glucose and promote the release of glucose into the bloodstream.
  • Instead of promoting glucose breakdown, glucagon promotes glucose production and release.

Gluconeogenesis (Option B): Stimulates the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources (amino acids, lactate) in the liver.

Glycogenolysis (Option C): Stimulates the breakdown of glycogen into glucose in the liver to release glucose into the bloodstream.

Ketogenesis (Option D): Stimulates the production of ketone bodies in the liver from fatty acids during periods of prolonged fasting or carbohydrate restriction.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for the deficiency causing classical galactosemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

Explanation:

Classical galactosemia is a genetic metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

  • This enzyme is essential for the proper metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

Role of GALT in Galactose Metabolism:

  • GALT converts galactose-1-phosphate to UDP-galactose, which is required for various biochemical processes, including the synthesis of glycoproteins and glycolipids.
  • A deficiency in GALT leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactose in tissues, which can cause toxicity and damage to the liver, kidneys, and brain, leading to the symptoms of classical galactosemia.

Clinical Features of Classical Galactosemia:

  • Failure to thrive and jaundice in the neonatal period after feeding with milk.
  • Liver damage, cataracts, intellectual disability, and sepsis from E. coli infections (due to impaired immune function).

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated galactose-1-phosphate in red blood cells.
  • Genetic testing for mutations in the GALT gene.

Treatment:

  • Lactose-free diet (avoiding galactose) to prevent the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites.

Aldose reductase (Option A): Involved in the reduction of galactose to galactitol, which is implicated in galactose toxicity but is not the enzyme deficient in classical galactosemia.

Galactokinase (Option B): Deficiency causes galactokinase deficiency or non-classical galactosemia, which leads to cataract formation but does not cause the systemic effects seen in classical galactosemia (liver damage, intellectual disability).

UDP-galactose-4-epimerase (Option D): Deficiency causes epimerase-deficient galactosemia, a less common form of galactosemia with milder symptoms than classical galactosemia.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency causesVon Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

Explanation:

Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme responsible for the final step of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Pathophysiology:

  • Impaired conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • Leads to glycogen accumulation in the liver and kidneys, causing hepatomegaly and severe hypoglycemia.

Key symptoms:

  • Severe fasting hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and hyperlipidemia

Liver phosphorylase (Option A): Deficiency causes Hers disease (GSD VI).

Lysosomal glucosidase (Option B): Deficiency causes Pompe disease (GSD II).

Hepatic glycogen synthase (Option C): Deficiency causes GSD 0 (reduced glycogen storage).

questions.text: What are the main substrate and metabolic fuel used by RBCs during fasting?
questions.solution:
RBCs cannot use fatty acid or ketone bodies as fuel during fasting as they do not have mitochondria where beta-oxidation of fatty acid occurs. Since ketone bodies and free fatty acids are utilized via beta-oxidation which occurs in mitochondria, RBCs cannot utilize them. RBC uses glucose as a substrate for energy production in the fed, fasting, and starvation state.

Ketone body (Option A) are used as a substrate for energy production during starvation phase by vital organs brain and heart primarily. Muscles use FA and ketone bodies for energy during starvation to avoid using proteins as fuel to prevent muscle loss.

Amino acid (Option C) is used by liver as a fuel in starvation state. It is the major source of fuel for the body in a starvation state.

Free fatty acid (Option D) is used as a fuel in fasting state by

  • Heart (uses fatty acid in both fed and fasting state )
  • Liver
  • Muscle
  • Adipose tissue (uses fatty acid in both fasting and starvation state)

Which of the following diagnostic markers is /are incorrectly paired?

1. Beta glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke disease

2. Lipase - Acute pancreatitis

3. Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration

4. High LDH1: LDH2 ratio -  Myocardial infarction

Von Gierke disease is a glycogen storage disease. The enzyme deficient is glucose 6 phosphatase present in the liver.

questions.text: A patient with thiamine deficiency develops lactic acidosis. Which of the following enzymes is affected?
questions.solution:
Thiamine (vitamin B1) is an essential coenzyme involved in several metabolic pathways, including the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA through the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC).

 

When deficient, the activity of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is impaired. As a result, there is a buildup of pyruvate. This pyruvate is then diverted to other metabolic pathways, like the conversion to lactic acid (lactate), resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Thiamine deficiency:

The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.

When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.

 

Conditions

Biochemical Role of Thiamine

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function

Peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations.

Wet Beriberi

Thiamine is necessary for the PDH complex and low activity causes Lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis causes vasodilatation and hence cardiovascular manifestations.

Cardiovascular manifestations such as oedema, palpitations, breathlessness, and heart failure.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids

Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

Lactic Acidosis

Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA

Impaired conversion leads to increased lactate and pyruvate levels, causing lactic acidosis.


 

Pyruvate carboxylase (Option A) is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. Pyruvate carboxylase is responsible for the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in an anaplerotic reaction that replenishes TCA cycle intermediates. It is not directly affected by thiamine deficiency in the context of lactic acidosis.

 

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (Option C) is responsible for the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), an important step in gluconeogenesis. It is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and is not typically affected by thiamine deficiency.


Transketolase (Option D) is involved in the non-oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), which generates ribose-5-phosphate and other sugars. Transketolase requires thiamine pyrophosphate as a cofactor.

questions.text: Which of the following poisoning agent does not inhibit cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: C) Methane

Explanation:

Cytochrome c oxidase is complex 4 in the electron transport chain. It is inhibited by the following:

  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulfide

Thus, cytochrome oxidase is not inhibited by methane.

questions.text: Which one of the options provided does not serve as a substrate for the synthesis of glucose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acetyl-CoA

Explanation: Acetyl-CoA is NOT a substrate for gluconeogenesis. Although acetyl-CoA is an important metabolic intermediate, it cannot be converted to glucose because the reaction catalysed by pyruvate dehydrogenase is irreversible.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis:

  • Lactate (Option D): Produced during anaerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscles and can be converted back to glucose in the liver through the Cori cycle.
  • Glycerol (Option B) is released from the breakdown of triglycerides in adipose tissue and can enter the gluconeogenesis pathway.
  • Alanine (Option C) and Glutamine: Released from the breakdown of proteins, primarily in muscle tissue.
  • Alanine is converted to pyruvate, which enters the gluconeogenesis pathway as part of the glucose-alanine (Cahill) cycle.
  • Propionate: Obtained from the metabolism of odd-chain fatty acids.

Cori’s cycle/ Glucose Lactate cycle and Cahill cycle/Glucose Alanine cycle

questions.text: In this scenario, what is the origin of the blood glucose measured at 7 am the following morning for an individual who had dinner at 8 pm the previous night?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hepatic glycogenolysis

Explanation:

During fasting:

  • After 4-16 hrs, the primary source of glucose is glycogenolysis
  • After 16-48 hrs, the primary source of glucose is gluconeogenesis (Option B)

Gluconeogenesis:

  • It is a process in which glucose is synthesized by non-carbohydrate sources such as amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionyl CoA.
  • The major site of gluconeogenesis the liver> kidney.

 

 

Regulation of gluconeogenesis:

  • Glucagon activates fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase and inhibits PFK-1, favoring gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glycolysis
  • The availability of substrates such as alanine, lactate, and glycerol favors gluconeogenesis
  • Acetyl CoA is an allosteric activator of 1st regulatory step of gluconeogenesis (pyruvate carboxylase)

Muscle glycogenolysis (Option C) is used during exercise and muscle activity.

Dietary glucose (Option D) is used in the first 4 hrs after meals.

questions.text: A baby is being evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Microscopic image of the bone marrow evaluation shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gaucher disease

 

Explanation:

Gaucher disease, caused by a defect in beta- glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide (glucocerebroside) within macrophages.

  • Lysosomal storage disorder of autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • These macrophages, engorged with glucosylceramide, are known as Gaucher cells.
  • The accumulation affects the bone marrow and spleen, leading to anaemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Gaucher cells have characteristic appearance of crumbled tissue paper look due to accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cytoplasm of macrophages, forming fibril like structures.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presented with easy fatigability, irritability and inability to concentrate. Labs revealed the following findings a and b (light and oil immersion respectively) on the bone marrow aspiration. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • The Clinical scenario of easy fatiguability, irritability and inability to concentrate along with the microscopic findings of crumpled tissue appearance of macrophages.
  • Gaucher's disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucosylceramide in RBCs and platelet membranes due to a deficiency in the enzyme Glucocerebrosidase, leading to anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance.

Gaucher's disease:

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Defective enzyme: Glucocerebrosidase
  • Defect in metabolism: Accumulation of cerebroside (Glucosylceramide) in RBCs and platelet membranes. (Option B)
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal RBCs and platelets are engulfed by macrophages leading to accumulation inside macrophages causing wrinkled paper appearance.

  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because

choices.text: It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is compact

Explanation:

  • Glycogen is a polysaccharide composed of many glucose molecules linked together through alpha-1,4-glycosidic bonds and branched with alpha-1,6-glycosidic bonds.
  • By storing glucose as glycogen, the body can efficiently pack a large amount of glucose molecules into a compact and readily available form.
  • This compact storage allows for efficient storage of glucose within cells, especially in tissues such as the liver and muscles, where glycogen serves as a reserve energy source.

 

It has multiple reducing ends (Option B): While it is true that glycogen has multiple reducing ends due to its branched structure, this is not the primary reason why glucose is stored as glycogen.

It can be stored at multiple organs (Option C): Although glycogen can be stored in multiple organs, such as the liver and muscles, this is not the main reason why glucose is stored as glycogen.

It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed (Option D): The storage capacity of glycogen varies depending on the individual and their glycogen reserves.

questions.text: What is the enzyme that is shared by both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Phosphoglycerate kinase

Phosphoglycerate kinase is involved in a reversible reaction in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  • Glycolysis: Converts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate, generating ATP.
  • Gluconeogenesis: Reverses the above reaction, utilizing ATP to convert 3-phosphoglycerate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate.

The other enzymes listed are specific to one pathway:

  • Pyruvate kinase (Option A): Specific to glycolysis (irreversible).
  • Phosphofructokinase (Option B): Specific to glycolysis (irreversible).
  • Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (Option C): Specific to gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: -


	Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids
	Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell
	Decreased acetyl CoA in TCA cycle
	Increase beta-hydroxy butyryl synthase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 2,3 and 4

Ketosis in Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) occurs due to the following mechanisms:

  • Increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue (statement 2): Lack of insulin leads to unregulated lipolysis, releasing free fatty acids (FFAs) into the bloodstream.
  • Decreased acetyl-CoA utilization in the TCA cycle (statement 3): Due to the depletion of oxaloacetate (used for gluconeogenesis in a hyperglycemic state), acetyl-CoA from beta-oxidation cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently and is diverted toward ketone body synthesis.
  • Increased activity of beta-hydroxybutyryl-CoA synthase (statement 4): This enzyme catalyzes the synthesis of ketone bodies (e.g., beta-hydroxybutyrate), contributing to ketosis.

Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids (Statement 1) because beta-oxidation is actually increased in T1DM due to elevated fatty acid mobilization and lack of insulin-mediated inhibition.

questions.text: Gluconeogenesis is mainly seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Liver:

  • The liver is the main organ responsible for gluconeogenesis. It converts non-carbohydrate precursors, such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids, into glucose to maintain blood glucose levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kidney: While the kidney plays a role in gluconeogenesis, the primary site for gluconeogenesis is the liver.

Option C - Spleen: The spleen is not a primary site for gluconeogenesis. It plays a role in the immune system and blood filtration.

Option D - Heart: The heart is not a significant site for gluconeogenesis. The primary metabolic activity of the heart involves utilizing various energy substrates, including fatty acids.

questions.text:
A child presents with fatigue and hepatomegaly. Liver enzymes (ALT, AST) are elevated. Ketosis was significant. Liver biopsy shows excess glycogen accumulation. After feeding, blood glucose levels rise, but there is no rise in glucose after overnight fasting.

Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Explanation:

The child’s presentation—fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, marked ketosis, glycogen accumulation in the liver, fasting hypoglycemia with normal postprandial glucose—strongly points toward a Glucose-6-phosphatase (G6PD) deficiency

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

 

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

 

Liver phosphorylase (GSD VI – Hers disease) (Option B) causes mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, but symptoms are less severe. Gluconeogenesis is intact, so fasting hypoglycemia and ketosis are not as pronounced as in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Muscle phosphorylase (GSD V – McArdle disease) (Option C) affects only skeletal muscle. Presents with exercise intolerance and muscle cramps, not fasting hypoglycemia or hepatomegaly.

 

Phosphofructokinase (GSD VII – Tarui disease) (Option D) involves muscle and red blood cells. Causes muscle pain and hemolysis, but does not affect the liver or cause fasting hypoglycemia.

Learning Objectives:

 

Glycogen Storage Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Type 0

Glycogen synthase deficiency

Type I (von Gierke's Disease)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Type II (Pompe's Disease)

Acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Type III (Cori's Disease)

Debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase)

Type IV (Andersen's Disease)

Branching enzyme

Type V (McArdle's Disease)

Muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)

Type VI (Hers' Disease)

Liver phosphorylase

Type VII (Tarui's Disease)

Phosphofructokinase (muscle type)

questions.text: Cancer cells take up excess glucose because?

choices.text: Lactate is produced even in the presence of Oxygen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lactate is produced even in the presence of Oxygen

Explanation:

Cancer cells demonstrate the Warburg Effect by favoring the conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of adequate oxygen, a process known as aerobic glycolysis.

  • The phenomenon in cancer cells where, even in the presence of oxygen, glucose is primarily converted to lactate through aerobic glycolysis. (Option A)
  • Significance:
    • This allows faster ATP production and provides intermediates for neoplastic cell growth and multiplication.
    • It increases NADPH production, protecting neoplastic cells from oxidative stress.

 

High NADH/NAD ratio (Option B): Although the NADH/NAD⁺ balance affects cellular metabolism, it is not the primary reason cancer cells take up excess glucose. The Warburg effect drives increased glucose uptake regardless of NADH levels.
 

High GLUT2 (Option C): GLUT2 is a glucose transporter mainly found in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and kidney, not commonly involved in cancer cell glucose uptake. Cancer cells typically overexpress GLUT1 or other transporters to increase glucose intake.
 

Absence of Oxygen (Option D): While low oxygen (hypoxia) can stimulate glucose uptake, many cancer cells continue to produce lactate and consume large amounts of glucose even when oxygen is plentiful, which is the hallmark of aerobic glycolysis, not simply hypoxia-induced metabolism.

questions.text: After a high-carbohydrate meal, weight gain is explained by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mitochondrial carnitine

Explanation:

After a high-carbohydrate meal, excess glucose is converted into fatty acids and stored as fat, contributing to weight gain.

 

This process involves:

  • Malonyl CoA: An intermediate in fatty acid synthesis that inhibits fatty acid oxidation.
  • Tricarboxylate transporter: Transports citrate from mitochondria to cytosol, providing acetyl-CoA for fatty acid synthesis.
  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: The key enzyme that converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, initiating fatty acid synthesis.

 

Mitochondrial carnitine (Option D) transports fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation (fat breakdown). After a high-carb meal, fat oxidation is inhibited, so mitochondrial carnitine doesn't contribute to weight gain.

questions.text: A breastfed infant presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and cataracts. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALPUT):

Explanation:

  • The infant’s lethargy, hepatomegaly, and cataracts after breastfeeding indicate classic galactosemia caused by Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency, leading to toxic buildup of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol, resulting in liver damage, cataracts, and neurological issues.

Classic Galactosemia

Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency

(Option B)
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate.
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

  1. Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis
  2. Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,
  3. Severe mental retardation
  4. Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)
  5. Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens
  6. Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

Incorrect Options:

  • Galactokinase (Option A) causes isolated cataracts but milder disease without severe liver involvement.
  • Aldolase B (Option C) causes hereditary fructose intolerance, presenting with hypoglycemia and liver problems after fructose ingestion.
  • Fructokinase (Option D) causes essential/fructosuria, a benign condition without serious symptoms.

questions.text: If glucose is increased 2-3 times the normal consumption and maintained at this level, what will happen in this condition?

choices.text: Initial rise and followed by increase levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sudden rise and sustained drop

Explanation:

In a chronic high-glucose condition, insulin secretion initially spikes but then progressively declines and stays low due to feedback inhibition and beta-cell exhaustion.

  • Initial response: High glucose → sudden surge in insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells.
  • Sustained high glucose: Prolonged stimulation causes β-cell fatigue and feedback inhibition.
  • Result: Insulin secretion drops and remains below initial peak levels (sustained drop). (Option C ruled out)
  • Physiological significance: Prevents overstimulation and β-cell exhaustion.
  • Clinical relevance: Chronic hyperglycemia can lead to β-cell dysfunction, impaired insulin release, and diabetes progression. (Option A)

Continuous increase in insulin (Option B): Insulin secretion cannot keep increasing indefinitely because beta cells eventually become exhausted or desensitized.

Initial rise and followed by increase levels (Option D): Insulin levels don’t continue to rise after the initial surge; they typically decline or plateau due to regulatory feedback.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise forgot to eat a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Which of the following metabolic processes is inhibited by alcohol consumption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gluconeogenesis

Explanation

Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis. Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio in the liver, which inhibits key enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia, especially in a fasting state after strenuous exercise.

  • Alcohol produces a high NADH/NAD+ ratio in the cytoplasm, the high NADH level favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of pyruvate leads to inadequate formation of oxaloacetate which blocks gluconeogenesis
  • This results in low blood sugar levels.
  • Symptoms of alcohol-induced hypoglycemia include confusion, irritability, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness.

 

Glycogenolysis (Option B): Glycogenolysis is generally stimulated by alcohol consumption due to the liver's attempt to maintain glucose levels. While alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis, it does not directly inhibit glycogenolysis.

HMP shunt (Option C): The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt is primarily involved in the production of NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate. Alcohol does not directly inhibit this pathway.

Ketone body formation (Option D): Ketone body formation can actually be promoted in alcohol consumption as the body shifts to using fatty acids for energy when glucose is unavailable.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Gluconeogenesis

 

Explanation:

  • Alcohol metabolism increases NADH/NAD+ ratio:
    • Ethanol is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to excessive NADH production.
  • Inhibition of Gluconeogenesis:
    • High NADH shifts metabolic balance, preventing conversion of lactate to pyruvate and malate to oxaloacetate, both of which are essential for gluconeogenesis.
  • Hypoglycemia Risk:
    • After exercise and fasting, glycogen stores are depleted.
    • The body relies on gluconeogenesis for glucose, but alcohol blocks this pathway, leading to hypoglycemia after drinking.

Alcohol-Induced Hypoglycemia

Feature

Effect of Alcohol

Key Mechanism

↑ NADH inhibits gluconeogenesis

Primary Effect

↓ Glucose production → Hypoglycemia

Clinical Features

Weakness, dizziness, confusion, seizures

Risk Factors

Fasting, exercise, malnutrition, chronic alcoholism

Treatment

IV dextrose, thiamine in alcoholics
  • Glycogenolysis (Option B): Incorrect because alcohol does not directly inhibit glycogen breakdown. However, after prolonged fasting, glycogen stores are already depleted.
  • Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt (Option C): Incorrect because this pathway primarily generates NADPH for anabolic processes and does not significantly contribute to blood glucose levels.
  • Ketone Body Formation (Option D): Incorrect because alcohol metabolism can actually promote ketogenesis, especially in chronic alcoholism, rather than inhibiting it.

questions.text: During starvation, which of the following hormones is primarily produced to maintain blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Glucagon

 

Explanation:

  • Role of Glucagon in Starvation:
    • During starvation, glucagon is the primary hormone that maintains blood glucose levels.
    • It promotes gluconeogenesis (glucose synthesis) and glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen) in the liver.
    • Increases lipolysis in adipose tissue, providing free fatty acids for energy.
  • Phases of Starvation:
    • Early fasting (first few hours): Blood glucose is maintained by glycogenolysis.
    • Prolonged fasting (after 24 hours): Gluconeogenesis becomes the primary glucose source, with glucagon playing a key role.
    • Later starvation (after 3-5 days): Ketogenesis increases as an alternative fuel.

Hormonal Changes in Starvation

Hormone

Effect in Starvation

Glucagon

Increases to stimulate gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

Insulin

Decreases to reduce glucose uptake by tissues.

Cortisol

Increases to promote protein catabolism for gluconeogenesis.

Epinephrine

Increases to enhance glycogen breakdown and lipolysis.

Growth Hormone (GH)

Increases to reduce glucose utilization and promote lipolysis.
  • Insulin (Option B): Incorrect because insulin decreases during starvation to limit glucose uptake by tissues.
  • Amylase (Option C): Incorrect because amylase is a digestive enzyme, not a hormone involved in blood glucose regulation.
  • Somatostatin (Option D): Incorrect because somatostatin inhibits both insulin and glucagon but does not directly regulate blood glucose during starvation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

Explanation

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting step of the HMP pathway. It catalyzes the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone, generating NADPH, which is critical for reductive biosynthesis and maintaining cellular redox balance.
  • The pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) is essential in erythrocytes because it generates NADPH. NADPH is crucial for maintaining glutathione in its reduced form, which is necessary for the activity of glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme removes harmful hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage and preventing hemolysis.

Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP)

The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt, is an alternative metabolic pathway for glucose that doesn't generate ATP.

Location: Cytosol
It serves two primary functions:

NADPH Production
  • The PPP is a major source of NADPH, vital for biosynthesis (fatty acids and steroids).
  • NADPH Production: RBCs rely on glycolysis for ATP due to the lack of mitochondria and depend solely on the PPP for NADPH, as they lack mitochondrial dehydrogenases.
  • Glutathione Maintenance: NADPH keeps glutathione reduced, enabling glutathione peroxidase to neutralize hydrogen peroxide and prevent oxidative damage.
  • Impact of NADPH Deficiency: Low NADPH reduces glutathione, impairs glutathione peroxidase, increases oxidative damage, and leads to hemolysis.

Ribose-5-Phosphate (R-5-P) Synthesis
  • Ribose-5-phosphate is essential for nucleotide synthesis needed for RNA and DNA.

Homeostasis between NADPH and R-5-P

production.
  • When NADPH demand exceeds R-5-P's need, the non-oxidative phase converts R-5-P to glycolytic intermediates (fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate).
  • If the demand for R-5-P is higher than for NADPH, the non-oxidative phase generates R-5-P from fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, bypassing the oxidative steps.

Differences from Glycolysis
  • Uses NADP+ instead of NAD+ and generates CO2, not ATP.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option A): This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose during gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. It is not involved in the HMP pathway.

Phosphofructokinase-1 (Option C): This enzyme is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis, not the HMP pathway.

Glycogen phosphorylase (Option D): This enzyme catalyzes the breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis and is not related to the HMP pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency is found in congenital lactic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pyruvate dehydrogenase:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) is a crucial enzyme that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • A deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase leads to congenital lactic acidosis.
  • Without functional PDH, pyruvate accumulates and is shunted to lactate production, leading to elevated lactate levels in the blood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Transketolase:

  • Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway, which helps in the production of NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate
  • A deficiency in transketolase is not associated with congenital lactic acidosis.

Option B - Branched chain Ketoacid dehydrogenase:

  • This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine).
  • A deficiency in branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase leads to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), not congenital lactic acidosis. MSUD is characterized by the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and their corresponding keto acids.

Option C - Isocitrate dehydrogenase:

  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in the citric acid cycle that helps in the conversion of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, producing NADPH or NADH in the process
  • While important in the citric acid cycle, a deficiency in isocitrate dehydrogenase is not typically associated with congenital lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following is excreted in the urine of patients with pentosuria?

L-Xylulose is excreted in the urine of patients with essential pentosuria, a rare benign metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of L-xylulose reductase. This leads to the accumulation and urinary excretion of L-xylulose, which can be mistaken for glucose in urine tests, but patients remain asymptomatic with no metabolic consequences.

Deficiency of L-xylulose reductase

Increased excretion of L-xylulose in urine

Clinical Symptoms

None (asymptomatic)

No treatment needed

D-Ribulose (Option C) is incorrect because it is an intermediate in the pentose phosphate pathway but is not associated with pentosuria.

 

D-Lactose (Option D) is incorrect because lactose is a disaccharide and is not involved in pentose metabolism or pentosuria.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the clinic with jaundice and a white, punctate, and scattered opacity in the central lens. The condition is consistent with Oil drop cataract. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Galactosemia:

  • The most likely metabolic disorder responsible for the presentation of oil drop cataract in a newborn infant with jaundice and lens opacities is Galactosemia. Oil drop cataract is a type of cataract characterized by small, white, punctate opacities that resemble oil drops in the lens of the eye. This specific type of cataract is associated with galactosemia, which is an inherited metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
  • In galactosemia, there is a deficiency in one of the enzymes involved in the metabolism of galactose, leading to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, including the lens of the eye. The accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate can result in the formation of the characteristic oil drop opacities seen in the lens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phenylketonuria (PKU): Phenylketonuria is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This leads to the buildup of phenylalanine in the body. However, PKU is not associated with oil drop cataract; instead, it can lead to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and other neurological problems if left untreated.

Option B - Maple syrup urine disease: This is a metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). It can cause neurological symptoms and a characteristic sweet odor to the urine. It is not associated with oil drop cataract.

Option D - Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease is a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. It can cause various neurological and hepatic symptoms. It is not associated with oil drop cataract.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the OPD with hypoglycemia and muscle cramps, on exertion or while playing. Then he becomes normal after resting for a while. These episodes are recurrent after a period of activity. He has decreased serum lactate and glucose levels. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) McArdle disease

Explanation:

  • McArdle's Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type V is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme muscle phosphorylase. This enzyme is essential for glycogen breakdown in muscle cells.
  • Patients with McArdle's disease typically present with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after strenuous activity.

 

Hers' Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI (Option B): It results from a deficiency in liver phosphorylase. While it does cause hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia, the symptoms are generally milder.

Andersen disease (Option D): This condition involves a deficiency in the Glycogen branching enzyme, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and death before age 5 due to heart or liver failure

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. The enzyme most likely deficient is

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in low insulin:glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Activation of hormone-sensitive lipase

Explanation:

Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is activated in response to low insulin:glucagon ratio.

HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol, providing energy during fasting.

  • Insulin:Glucagon Bipolar Axis:
    • Insulin: Anabolic hormone promoting glycogenesis, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis.
    • Glucagon: Catabolic hormone stimulating glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis.
    • IGR:
      • High IGR → Anabolic state, reduced glucose production.
      • Low IGR → Catabolic state, increased glucose production.
  • Determinants of IGR:
    • Influenced by insulin and glucagon secretion patterns, dietary composition, and metabolic status.
    • Variability in systemic and portal concentrations complicates measurement accuracy.

Activation of lipoprotein lipase (Option A):

  • Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin, not glucagon.
  • It facilitates triglyceride uptake from circulating lipoproteins into adipose tissue for storage, which occurs in the fed state.

Activation of glycogen synthase (Option B): Glycogen synthase is activated by insulin, promoting glycogen synthesis in the liver and muscle during the fed state.

Activation of phosphofructokinase (Option C): Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is a key enzyme in glycolysis. It is activated by insulin and suppressed during fasting (low insulin:glucagon ratio), as glycolysis is reduced in favor of gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to feeding difficulties, vomiting, and failure to thrive. The child's history reveals that the infant was born full-term and had a normal birth weight. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced, and the liver is palpable below the costal margin. Oil drop Cataracts are also noted on eye examination. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of galactose in the blood and urine. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) GALT (Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase) deficiency

Explanation:

  • GALT deficiency, also known as galactosemia, is a genetic disorder that impairs the ability to metabolize galactose properly. Galactose is a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

 

Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option A)
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis

Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,

Severe mental retardation

Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)

Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens

Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

  • Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis
  • Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,
  • Severe mental retardation
  • Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)
  • Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens, reversible cataract
  • Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) (Option A) is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This leads to the buildup of phenylalanine in the body. It can lead to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and other neurological problems if left untreated.

Maple syrup urine disease (Option B) is a metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). It can cause neurological symptoms and a characteristic sweet odor to the urine.

Wilson's disease (Option D) is a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. It can cause various neurological and hepatic symptoms.
